So here it is - the story so far. A singer/songwriter lauded by his peers and
cited by such publications as the NME as sufficiently important as to being
required to be taught in schools. However the NME heyday as as important
indicators of talent and importance are long gone; it now being staffed by
stringers and a passionless ner do wells. We shall see for ourselves The album
is in chronological order and takes the listener on a trip that illustrates
BruntnellÃƒâ€ s development as a songwriter as well as an arranger and performer.
The early stuff from ÃƒÂ¦CannibalÃƒâ€  and ÃƒÂ¦Camelot and SmithereensÃƒâ€  is hard to date
and hard to classify although the cracked vocal is mixed low but still to the
fore. The arrangement on ÃƒÂ¦25 ReasonsÃƒâ€  owes much to Jack NietzcheÃƒâ€ s work for the
Buffalo Springfield with its dreamy and somnambulant quality. The seeds had
been
sown.

The Rykodisc contributions from ÃƒÂ¦Normal for BridgewaterÃƒâ€  move Bruntnell
forward,
positing the theory that although a songwriter he is also a singer and band
leader carving out big sounds fit for arenas. ÃƒÂ¦Shot from a SpringÃƒâ€  has all the
pedigree of a show stopper and indeed when performed with a full band can bring
the house down as the guitars drift and yearn through the melodies. The Loose
years begin with BruntnellÃƒâ€ s very own ÃƒÂ¦PowderfingerÃƒâ€  - ÃƒÂ¦Here Come the SwellsÃƒâ€  a
swaggering slice of American rock anglicised by the understated vocal delivery
yet still a towering, melancholy masterpiece with its cushion of guitars and
punchy harmonies. These are all deeply commercial songs that hold onto their
honesty and truth through careful production and a great sense artistry. The
joy
to be had listening to the Bruntnell/ James WalbourneÃƒâ€ s acoustic duet of ÃƒÂ¦By
The
Time My Head Gets To PhoenixÃƒâ€  does not diminish - two guys , guitars, great
song
and sumptuous vocals. WhatÃƒâ€ s not to like?? By the time we reach the tracks from
the album Ghost in a Spitfire there is a sense of both artist and label
reaching
for the commercial breakthrough. These are massive songs and designed to be
heard by the masses. Then frustration or restlessness leads to a left turn
which
produces the wonderful and shapeshifting songs from ÃƒÂ¦Peter and a Murder of

and
heft that exists within the swirling drones and Traffic like pastoralism. Still
the cracked clear vocals and excellent production but a road less travelled,
the
harmonium, the cellos and the hushed drums belying the beauty and bathos.
Stunning stuff. ÃƒÂ¦Black Mountain UFOÃƒâ€  provides the penultimate tracks - breezy
Americana with a hint of English psychedelia although ÃƒÂ¦Ghost DogÃƒâ€  owes as much
to YoungÃƒâ€ s ÃƒÂ¦Southern ManÃƒâ€ . We finish with the bid for a hit - an old track
ÃƒÂ¦Played OutÃƒâ€  with added Rumer. ItÃƒâ€ s wonderful and her vocal fits like a glove .
Unnecessary but a great collaboration and this reviewer for one hope it does
the
trick. And what would that trick be? Sufficient commercial success to enable
Bruntnell to continue writing and performing without worrying about the next
quid so he can add to his exquisite back catalogue or massive public acceptance
leading to untold wealth and stadium tours and celebrity tie ins? I hope the
former but if heÃƒâ€ s after the latter then he deserves that too. This is is a
near
perfect album spoilt only by a lack of certain other songs and its title. It
should have been called be ÃƒÂ¦An introductionÃƒâ€  or ÃƒÂ¦ The songs you should know by
nowÃƒâ€  but what do I know. Top work!
